{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3583963,"name":"chase steenhoven","username":"chaseeeeey127","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/3da27b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T17:11:40.053Z","cooked":"

I have been working on a esp32 based kiwi-drive robot for the better part of a year now. I would like to be able to connect to it using the actual driverstation app, and then use the controller by proxy. Is this possible, given the lack of open source data on NI driverstation, and low processing power of the eps32?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-04-08T17:11:40.053Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":197,"readers_count":196,"score":134.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":498451,"topic_slug":"looking-to-use-driverstation-app-with-a-esp32-based-personal-robot","display_username":"chase steenhoven","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70593,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team captain"},"post_url":"/t/looking-to-use-driverstation-app-with-a-esp32-based-personal-robot/498451/1","custom_user_title":"Team captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3584048,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T18:12:31.493Z","cooked":"

There’s some info from a prior reverse engineering effort here. (I have no idea how complete it is.)

The ESP should have plenty of processing power for basic robotics operation. I’d put it at around 25% of the processing power of a Rio, which has way more than enough power to run a robot.

25% may be generous

Technically possible? Probably.
Worth while? Likely not.

What functionality are you wanting?

Read USB joysticks and send scaled values to the device? (Something else?)

mostly just want it for novel reasons. I already have it operating via bluetooth direct to ps5 controller. I may add a dedicated esp32 running a web server, and make a DS looking site. espnow works very well for inter- esp communications.

If this is mostly for a “coolness” factor, it would probably be a lot easier to build a similarly looking site (or even desktop app) that implements just the features you’re using.

The Driver Station relies on a stack of technology that the rio has either baked in or included in the image or team code (mDNS, using particular ports both in TCP and UDP, reporting lots of data, polling for game mode every 20 mS, polling for joystick position every 20 mS but only in telep, to name a few).

You might be able to hook into the same simulation hooks used for the XRP and Romi kits to be used with WPILIB, and that natively supports the drive station.

Albeit this probably isn’t what you’re looking for, I was also looking for something like this a few years back. I used an ESP32 for a small mecanum bot and wanted an interface like the FRC Driverstation, although it most definitely is not that, I modeled a TCP Driverstation in Vb.net that uses TCP to communicate with an ESP32.

github.com

GitHub - Tommy-Guo/TCP-Driver-Station: A Driver station for wireless robot communication...

A Driver station for wireless robot communication over TCP

You can take a look at it here, it’s open source. It doesn’t have anything like logs or anything super sophisticated, I wrote a custom theme that models the same look. It uses a library that takes input from a Xbox controller connected to your laptop’s USB ports.

This project has also never been updated, so do with it what you can.
